app.title: ScheduleVision
app.subtitle: A clear view of your project

intro.p1: My name is Ruslan Khisamov, I am a project manager specializing in capital project management in the mining and metallurgical industry. Oracle Primavera P6 is the industry standard for planning, coordination, and control of complex projects.
intro.p2: To view an Oracle Primavera P6 XER file, special software, licenses, and additional configuration are required. This reduces data accessibility and complicates fast managerial decision-making.
intro.p3: That is why I am creating ScheduleVision — a free and convenient web tool that allows you to open and analyze projects developed in Primavera P6 anywhere, without additional software. ScheduleVision makes working with schedules more transparent and analytics accessible to every project participant — whether manager, engineer, or contractor.
intro.p4: My goal is to contribute to the industry by offering a tool that helps make decisions faster, manage resources more effectively, and improve transparency in project management.

upload.title: Upload XER or XML File
upload.desc: Choose an Oracle Primavera P6 XER or XML file for local processing and viewing. All processing is done in your browser, and no data is sent to the server.
upload.btn_aria: Upload XER or XML file from local device
upload.hint: If you need to update the base file, click “Reload file”.

reload.btn_aria: Reload base XER or XML file

security.title: Security and Privacy
security.lead: ScheduleVision is designed with a priority on protecting your data:

items.local_only: Your files are not transmitted to the server — all processing is performed directly in your browser.
items.indexeddb: Data is stored only in the local database (IndexedDB) on your device.
items.analytics: Web files and cookies are used exclusively for visit analytics via Google services and do not affect the content of your projects.
items.control: You have full control of your data: you can delete saved files from your browser’s local database at any time.

security.outro: Thus, working with projects in ScheduleVision is safe, private, and fully under your control.

base_upload_desc: To get started, upload a .xer or .xml file from your device. The local database will be cleared on page load.
base_upload_hint: If you want to switch the dataset, reload a .xer or .xml file.

table.TRSRCFIN: Activity Resource Assignment Past Period Actuals

checkDesc.1: Activities without predecessor and/or successor (missing logic).
checkDesc.2: Percentage of relationships that are leads.
checkDesc.3: Percentage of relationships that use lags.
checkDesc.4: Share of FS relationships among all links.
checkDesc.5: Percentage of hard constraints among activities with constraints.
checkDesc.6: Percentage of activities with total float greater than working days.
checkDesc.7: Count of activities with negative total float.
checkDesc.8: Activities with remaining duration over threshold (e.g. 44d).
checkDesc.9: Forecast/actual dates that violate schedule logic.
checkDesc.11: Completed activities finished later than baseline.
checkDesc.12: Critical path continuity and reach of project finish.

empty.text: No extra parameters for the selected check. The global flags “Enable analysis” and “Show in table” are used.

calendar.note: Choose which calendar’s hours-per-day to use when converting lags or leads to hours/days.

filters.ignoreLoE: Ignore relations with Level of Effort activities
filters.ignoreWbsSummary: Ignore relations with WBS summary activities

notes.dcmaZero: Per DCMA-14, any leads are non-compliant (target = 0%). Thresholds below are for custom KPIs only and do not change the DCMA rule unless you disable the Strict rule.
notes.dcmaFive: DCMA recommends no more than 5% of relationships with positive lag.

visibility.showOnMain: Show this Health check on the main screen

note.kpiOnly: Custom KPI thresholds are for grading only. No hard requirement is enforced.
Thresholds below are used for grading only (management KPI).

mode.strictZero: Strict DCMA rule (no negative float allowed)
mode.note: If disabled, you can configure tolerances below.

tolerance.hours: Allowed total hours of negative float

check9.note: Invalid Dates: 9a counts activities where forecast (ES/EF/LS/LF) is earlier than the Data Date; 9b counts activities where actuals (AS/AF) are later than the Data Date. Use the tolerances below to offset comparisons by the specified number of days.

check10.note: All activities with effective duration ≥ %{days} days must have assigned resource(s). Effective duration is computed using the activity calendar's hours per day.

check12.simulatedNote: The test increases each critical activity’s duration by this amount and checks that the project finish slips accordingly.

dataDate.note: If set, calculations use this date instead of the project’s Data Date.

forecastSource.label: Use planned/forecast dates from
forecastSource.note: Choose which planned or forecast date set to use for CPLI (e.g., Early, Late).

note.kpiOnly: Thresholds below are used for grading only (management KPI).

dataDate.note: If set, BEI is computed as of this date instead of the project’s Data Date.

actuals.requireAF: Require Actual Finish to count as completed
actuals.note: When enabled, activities without Actual Finish are not considered completed for BEI.

note.kpiOnly: Thresholds below are used for grading only (management KPI).

1.title: Check 1: Logic
1.goal: Assess completeness of logical relationships between schedule activities.
1.check: All unfinished activities must have at least one predecessor and one successor. Only justified project start and finish events may be exceptions.
1.importanceMetrics: High. Without proper logic the schedule cannot support decision‑making and control.
1.frequency: When creating and at every update of the schedule.
1.description:
The first DCMA 14 check ensures that every activity in the project has both predecessors and successors. DCMA allows at most 5% of activities to lack a predecessor, a successor, or both—typically limited to justified start/finish milestones.

Missing links break schedule logic, prevent a correct critical path calculation, and distort float analysis. Incorrect predecessor–successor definitions can shift key milestone dates.

2.title: Check 2: Leads
2.goal: Identify and eliminate negative lags that distort execution sequence.
2.check: Find relationships with negative lag (leads), e.g., Finish‑Start with −30 days.
2.importanceMetrics: High. Leads distort float and critical path calculations and reduce schedule transparency.
2.frequency: During creation, updating, and correction of the schedule.
2.description:
A lead is an overlap (negative lag) between two linked activities such that the successor may start before the predecessor finishes. In tools it appears as a negative value in the "Lag" field.

DCMA 14 prohibits the use of leads. They mask logic, complicate float and critical path calculations, and may be interpreted inconsistently.

Preferred alternatives:

  • Use Start‑Start with a positive lag,
  • or insert an intermediate activity representing the overlap explicitly.

3.title: Check 3: Lags
3.goal: Control the use of positive lags in logic.
3.check: Analyze links with positive lag (e.g., FS +5 days) — their presence, count, and duration.
3.importanceMetrics: High. Positive lags hide real work and reduce transparency and manageability.
3.frequency: When forming, updating, and adjusting the schedule.
3.description:
A lag is a positive time offset between predecessor finish and successor start. DCMA 14 permits lags but limits them to no more than 5% of project links.

Best practice is to replace lags with explicit activities so scope and duration are visible and controllable. Use lags only with strong justification.

4.title: Check 4: Relationship Types
4.goal: Standardize dependencies and ensure a correct technological sequence of work.
4.check: Share of Finish‑Start (FS) links. DCMA 14 requires at least 90% of links to be FS.
4.importanceMetrics: Medium. Excessive SS, FF, and especially SF links reduce transparency and may distort the critical path.
4.frequency: When creating, editing, and updating the schedule.
4.description: DCMA favors FS links for clarity and controllability. SS and FF are acceptable in justified cases; SF should be rare and isolated.

5.title: Check 5: Hard Constraints
5.goal: Eliminate fixed dates that block schedule recalculation and reduce flexibility.
5.check: Count activities with hard constraints (Mandatory Start/Finish). DCMA recommends no more than 5% of all constraints.
5.importanceMetrics: High. Hard constraints make the schedule rigid and may break critical path calculation.
5.frequency: During creation, editing, and every update.
5.description:
Constraints define whether an activity obeys the schedule algorithm. Types:

  • Hard: Mandatory Start, Mandatory Finish.
  • Soft: As Late As Possible; Start On/Before/After; Finish On/Before/After.

DCMA 14 requires keeping hard constraints under 5% and favoring soft constraints, which preserve flexibility and correct analysis.

6.title: Check 6: High Float
6.goal: Detect tasks with excessive or unjustified float.
6.check: Count activities whose total float exceeds the threshold. DCMA cites >44 calendar days (often ~60 workdays in other methods) as a limit for no more than 5% of activities.
6.importanceMetrics: Medium. Excessive float may hide missing logic or link issues (checked elsewhere).
6.frequency: After schedule formation and on updates.
6.description: Total Float is how long an activity may slip without impacting key milestones. High float often indicates missing links or logic errors. Such "dangling" activities hinder risk analysis, distort the critical path, and reduce manageability. Reduce high‑float counts by refining logic.

7.title: Check 7: Negative Float
7.check: Presence of activities with negative total float.
7.importanceMetrics: High. Negative float signals slippage and demands immediate corrective action.
7.frequency: After formation and before each update.
7.description: Negative float commonly arises from hard constraints fixing dates regardless of logic, causing milestone breaches. Remove hard constraints or correct logic and status dates to restore feasibility.

8.title: Check 8: High Duration
8.goal: Increase manageability and detail of work packages.
8.check: Unfinished tasks longer than 44 workdays should be ≤5% of all activities.
8.importanceMetrics: Medium. Very long activities hide true sequencing and hinder control.
8.description: Over‑long activities usually bundle multiple steps, hide internal logic, and complicate monitoring and acceptance. Decompose to a manageable level to improve transparency and critical path accuracy.

9.title: Check 9: Invalid Dates
9.goal: Ensure correct status and schedule actualization.
9.check: Actual dates must not be later than the Data Date; forecast dates must not be earlier than the Data Date.
9.importanceMetrics: High. Invalid dates distort progress and indices (e.g., BEI).
9.frequency: At every update and reporting cycle.
9.description:
Two groups:

  • 9a. Forecast: early/late dates in the past often appear with negative float.
  • 9b. Actual: actual start/finish in the future (after Data Date) is invalid.

Validate dates each cycle to keep the schedule reliable.

10.title: Check 10: Resources
10.goal: Verify completeness of the resource model.
10.check: All activities with duration ≥1 day should have assigned resources or cost (labor, material, equipment, or cost type).
10.importanceMetrics: High. Without resources the schedule cannot represent effort, cost, or loading.
10.frequency: After resource planning and at each update.
10.description: Each ≥1‑day activity should have at least one resource. Some tasks may lack corporate resources (e.g., client approvals), but this check highlights gaps that could skew loading and cost control.

11.title: Check 11: Missed Tasks
11.goal: Assess execution against the baseline; identify late finishes.
11.check: Completed activities that finished later than their baseline finish should be ≤5%.
11.importanceMetrics: High. Late finishes indicate discipline and management issues.
11.frequency: At each project meeting during execution.
11.description:
Baseline Execution Index (BEI)

Formula:

BEI = Completed activities / Activities planned complete by the Data Date

Interpretation:

  • BEI = 1 → on plan.
  • BEI < 1 → behind plan.
  • BEI > 1 → ahead of plan (verify data).

Why BEI matters:

  1. Objective view of execution independent of cost/units.
  2. Quick gauge of team discipline.
  3. Useful for contractor KPIs and status assessment.

12.title: Check 12: Critical Path Test
12.goal: Test sensitivity of project finish to changes on the critical path.
12.check: If any critical activity’s duration is increased (e.g., +600 days), the project finish must slip by the same amount. A mismatch implies missing links and a broken critical chain.
12.importanceMetrics: High. A non‑responsive critical path means the schedule is not a controllable model.
12.frequency: After each logic change or task insertion.
12.description: The critical path must drive the project finish. If prolonging a critical task does not shift the finish, the logic is broken and requires detailed review.

13.title: Check 13: Critical Path Length Index (CPLI)
13.goal: Evaluate realism of completing on time versus the baseline.
13.check: Compute CPLI (balance between critical path length and available float). DCMA target is 1.0 ±5%.
13.importanceMetrics: High. Low CPLI indicates high risk of late completion despite normal progress.
13.frequency: Monthly, especially when revising dates and updates.
13.description:
CPLI interpretation:

  • > 1 — ahead with time reserve;
  • = 1 — on plan;
  • < 1 — at risk;
  • < 0.95 — systemic delay requiring action.

14.title: Check 14 Baseline Execution Index (BEI)
14.goal: Assess how actual execution matches the plan as of the status date.
14.check: Number of completed activities relative to those planned complete by the report date.
14.importanceMetrics: High. BEI highlights schedule slippage and the need for corrective actions.
14.frequency: At each project meeting, at least monthly.
14.description:
DCMA 14 treats BEI < 0.95 as delay requiring analysis.

  • BEI = 1 — on plan.
  • BEI > 1 — ahead (validate data).
  • BEI < 1 — behind plan.
  • BEI < 0.95 — systemic delay.

Why BEI:

  1. Transparent picture of execution independent of cost/units.
  2. Assesses team discipline.
  3. Supports contractor KPIs and schedule risk forecasting.

upload.btn_add_aria: Add candidate XER or XML file for comparison
upload.btn_reload_aria: Reload candidate XER or XML file

candidate_missing.title: Candidate not found
candidate_missing.desc1: Candidate file is not uploaded or candidate project is not selected.
candidate_missing.desc2: Upload a candidate file (.xer, .xml) to start the comparison.
candidate_missing.hint_select: After upload, select the candidate project in the dropdown.

errors.no_candidate_selected_or_loaded: Candidate not found: upload a file and select candidate project.
errors.failed: Failed to compare. Check selected projects and data.

info: ScheduleVision is fully compatible with Oracle® Primavera® P6®. It is an independently developed reader application created by Ruslan Khissamov. ScheduleVision is not a product of Oracle® and is neither endorsed, sponsored, nor affiliated with Oracle® Corporation.
